prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: Covenants Entered into After Formation of the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: The courts will distinguish between covenants made prior to the commencement of the employment relationship and those entered into after employment has commenced. For example, in Mercury Marine Ltd. v. Dillon,[1] the court emphasized that covenants entered into after employment has commenced will fall under a higher level of scrutiny:

… in this case there is a disparity in bargaining power. The evidence of the circumstances surrounding the execution by Dillon of the covenant persuades me that he was forced to sign it “with a gun at his head” and with the assurance that it had no practical application to his type of work. I am persuaded that the plaintiff took unfair advantage of Dillon in extracting the covenant from him at the time it had already agreed to employ him. Not only will the courts scrutinize it more rigorously but may well refuse to enforce it as a result.

Where an employee has already been hired, the courts will take a careful look at the circumstances surrounding the signing of any additional covenants. Unless a specific right to amend the contract of employment can be implied into the relationship, or unless the employee offers his or her consent to an amendment, the courts will normally look for additional consideration for the employee to avoid a conclusion that the covenant was imposed unilaterally by the employer.[2]
However, in the right circumstances, the courts have held that covenants may be enforceable even though they are entered into after the employment starts.[3]

Non-competition covenants have been held to be enforceable in situations where the continuance of employment was itself used as legal consideration. Covenants entered into as part of a settlement following the end of employment may also be enforced.[4]

In addition, it is important to point out that, where a covenant materially alters the existing employment contract and there is no significant consideration, there will be an argument that the employer constructively dismissed the employee.[5]

Accordingly, it is best to impose a restrictive covenant at the beginning of the employment relationship. If protection is desired later, the situation must justify the imposition of the covenant (e.g., due to a promotion or for financial consideration). In all cases, the circumstances of the signing should be fair and exemplary.
Mercury Marine Ltd. v. Dillon (1986), 30 D.L.R. (4th) 627 at pp. 630-31, 56 O.R. (2d) 266 (H.C.J.); MacQuarrie's Drugs Ltd. v. Salsman, 2012 CarswellNS 453, 2012 NSSC 234.
Gentle v. Mediacom Industries Inc. (1983), 24 A.C.W.S. (2d) 188 (Ont. H.C.J.); Johnston v. Merit Clothing Co. (1984), 24 A.C.W.S. (2d) 50 (Ont. S.C.).
See Future Shop v. Northwest-Atlantic (B.C.) Broker Inc. (2000), 2 C.P.C. (5th) 358 (B.C.S.C.).

See Gestion Trans-Tek Inc. v. Lampel (2001), 104 A.C.W.S. (3d) 860 (Ont. S.C.J.), at para. 27; Dimmer v. MMV Financial Inc., 2012 CarswellOnt 16012, 2012 ONSC 7257; Murrell v. Burns International Security Services Ltd., 1997 CarswellOnt 4093 (Ont. C.A.); Watson v. Moore Corp., 1996 CarswellBC 516 (B.C. C.A.); Ostrow v. Abacus Management Corp. Mergers & Acquisitions, 2014 CarswellBC 1482, 2014 BCSC 938; Link v. Venture Steel Inc., 2010 CarswellOnt 1049, 2010 ONCA 144; Rhebergen v. Creston Veterinary Clinic Ltd., 2014 CarswellBC 607, 2014 BCCA 97; Inglis v. Great-West Life Assurance Co., 1941 CarswellOnt 28, [1941] O.J. No. 366 (Ont. H.C.), reversed 1941 CarswellOnt 190 (Ont. C.A.); Nortel Networks Corp. v. Jervis, 2002 CarswellOnt 21, [2002] O.J. No. 12 (Ont. S.C.J.); Levinsky v. Toronto-Dominion Bank, 2013 CarswellOnt 12655, 2013 ONSC 5657 (Ont. S.C.J. [Commercial List]).

Of course, the employee, if successful with such an argument, is then entitled to all the normal damages that flow from dismissal without just cause. MacQuarrie's Drugs Ltd. v. Salsman, 2012 CarswellNS 453, 2012 NSSC 234.
